CISA MARKUP DAY IS HERE – The Senate Intelligence Committee will hold the highly anticipated — but closed-door — markup of its cyberthreat information sharing bill today, becoming the first committee in the 114 th to get moving on cyber legislation.

The Committee’s consideration of a bill like this, which will impact the privacy of Internet users worldwide, should never be undertaken behind closed doors,” said Greg Nojeim, senior counsel at the Center for Democracy & Technology

-- Not coincidentally, the Information Technology Industry Council late Wednesday put out their necessary elements for information sharing legislation.

Named the Brandeis program after former Supreme Court Justice Louis Brandeis, who first described a “right to privacy,” the program aims to “understand how to build information systems that can ensure private data can only be used for its intended purpose and no other.” DARPA kicked off the project with a broad agency announcement seeking data security proposals.

Lobbyists who have seen updated language (passed out in hard copy) said there had been some strengthening on the privacy protections, including clarifying the section on countermeasures to refer to “defensive measures,” requiring the federal government to strip PII before sharing like companies and tweaking how info can be disclosed, retained and used.

They are targeted liability protections, including from FOIA and antitrust actions; sharing in all directions between and within the private sector and government; keeping sharing voluntary; and privacy protections, including reasonable PII stripping requirements and limiting uses of information to cybersecurity purposes.
